case_vignette:
A 55-year-old man presents with bloody nasal secretions and shortness of breath. He reports he has lost 4 kg (8.8 lb) in the last two months with no changes in his diet. He has also been suffering from mild to moderate joint pain in the left knee for the last year. His past medical history is unremarkable. His vitals include: blood pressure 120/70 mm Hg, temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉), pulse 70/min, respiratory rate 14/min. Physical examination is significant for nasal ulcers. Diffuse crackles are present over all lobes of the lung bilaterally. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
Hemoglobin 12.9 g/dL
Hematocrit 37.7%
Leukocyte count 5500/mm3
Neutrophils 65%
Lymphocytes 30%
Monocytes 5%
Mean corpuscular volume 82.2 μm3
Platelet count 190,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 35 mm/h
C-reactive protein 14 mg/dL
Creatinine 3.09 mg/dL
The patient is prescribed a corticosteroid nasal spray and oral antibiotics but returns in 2 weeks without any clinical improvement.
question: Which  would most likely confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have bloody nasal secretions and shortness of breath.
Great, thank you for letting me know. Can you tell me, are you a smoker or have you had any recent exposure to smoke or pollutants?
No, I don't have a history of smoking or recent exposure to smoke or pollutants.
Okay, that's good to know. Have you noticed any other symptoms such as fever, cough, or fatigue?
No, I haven't had a fever or a cough, but I have been feeling more tired than usual.
Thank you for letting me know. Have you had any recent travel or exposure to anyone with similar symptoms?
No, I haven't traveled recently or been around anyone with similar symptoms.
Okay, that's good to know. Have you noticed any other symptoms such as joint pain or swelling, or any changes in your vision or hearing?
Yes, I've been suffering from mild to moderate joint pain in my left knee for the last year.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on the symptoms you've described, it's possible that you may have developed a condition called osteoarthritis in your left knee. Osteoarthritis is a common condition that affects the joints, causing pain, stiffness, and limited mobility. It can be caused by a variety of factors, including age, genetics, and joint injury.

I would recommend that you schedule an appointment with a rheumatologist for further evaluation and diagnosis. The rheumatologist will perform a thorough examination and may order imaging tests, such as X-rays or an MRI, to confirm the diagnosis and determine the best course of treatment.

In the meantime, you can try over-the-counter pain medications such as acetaminophen or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to help manage your symptoms. You can also try gentle exercises such as stretching and strengthening to help improve your knee mobility and reduce stiffness.

Please let me know if you have any other questions

In the meantime, I would like to ask you a few more questions to help us narrow down the possible causes of your symptoms. Can you tell me more about your nosebleeds? How often do you experience them, and how long do they last? Do you have any other symptoms, such as headaches or facial pain?

Thank you for letting me know. Based on what you've told me so far, it's possible that you have a condition called nasal bleeding or epistaxis. Nasal bleeding can be caused by a variety of factors, including dry air, allergies, colds, sinus infections, and injuries to the nose.

To confirm the diagnosis, I would like to perform a nasal endoscopy. This is a simple procedure in which a flexible tube with a camera on the end is inserted through your nostrils to visualize the inside of your nasal passages and sinuses. This will allow us to evaluate the inside of your nose and determine the cause of the bleeding.

Does this sound like a good idea to you?
Yes, that sounds like a good idea to me.

Great! I'm glad you're willing to undergo the nasal endoscopy. Based on what you've told me so far, it's possible that you have a condition called nasal polyps, which can cause bleeding and other symptoms.

During the procedure, we will use a nasal scope to visualize the inside of your nasal passages and sinuses. We will look for any abnormalities, such as nasal polyps, and take samples of any tissue that we find. These samples will be sent to a laboratory for further testing.

The procedure is usually done in an outpatient setting, and it should only take a few minutes to complete. You may experience some discomfort or pressure during the procedure, but it should not be painful.

After the procedure, we will discuss the results with you and recommend the best course of treatment based on what we find. This may include medications to shrink the nasal polyps, or in some cases, surgery to remove them.

Great, thank you for letting me know. I will schedule an appointment for you to come in within the next week. In the meantime, please start using the nasal spray as directed and let me know if you have any questions or concerns.

Also, I would like to schedule a follow-up appointment with you in 2-3 days to check on your progress and to see if the nasal spray is working effectively. Does that sound good to you?

Finally, I would like to remind you that if you experience any severe or persistent symptoms, such as heavy bleeding, facial pain, or difficulty breathing, you should seek medical attention immediately.

Thank you for your cooperation and I look forward to seeing you at your follow-up appointment.
That sounds good to me, and I will be sure to reach out if I experience any severe symptoms. Thank you, and I look forward to the follow-up appointment.

You're welcome! I'm glad you're willing to work with me to manage your symptoms. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns before your follow-up appointment. I'm here to help.

In the meantime, try to avoid blowing your nose too vigorously and use a humidifier to add moisture to the air in your home. This can help to reduce inflammation and irritation in your nasal passages.

I'll see you at your follow-up appointment in 2-3 days. Take care!
